sysprompt.name: Neutral - Chat
sysprompt.content: Write {{char}}'s next reply in a fictional chat between {{char}} and {{user}}.

memory.prompt: Ignore previous instructions. Summarize the most important facts and events in the story so far. If a summary already exists in your memory, use that as a base and expand with new facts. Limit the summary to {{words}} words or less. Your response should include nothing but the summary.

expressions.llmPrompt: Ignore previous instructions. Classify the emotion of the last message. Output just one word, e.g. "joy" or "anger". Choose only one of the following labels: {{labels}}

sd.negative_prompt: lowres, bad anatomy, bad hands, text, error, cropped, worst quality, low quality, normal quality, jpeg artifacts, signature, watermark, username, blurry

prompts.0: In the next response I want you to provide only a detailed comma-delimited list of keywords and phrases which describe {{char}}. The list must include all of the following items in this order: name, species and race, gender, age, clothing, occupation, physical features and appearances. Do not include descriptions of non-visual qualities such as personality, movements, scents, mental traits, or anything which could not be seen in a still photograph. Do not write in full sentences. Prefix your description with the phrase 'full body portrait,'
prompts.1: Ignore previous instructions and provide a detailed description of {{user}}'s physical appearance from the perspective of {{char}} in the form of a comma-delimited list of keywords and phrases. The list must include all of the following items in this order: name, species and race, gender, age, clothing, occupation, physical features and appearances. Do not include descriptions of non-visual qualities such as personality, movements, scents, mental traits, or anything which could not be seen in a still photograph. Do not write in full sentences. Prefix your description with the phrase 'full body portrait,'. Ignore the rest of the story when crafting this description. Do not reply as {{char}} when writing this description, and do not attempt to continue the story.
prompts.2: Ignore previous instructions and provide a detailed description for all of the following: a brief recap of recent events in the story, {{char}}'s appearance, and {{char}}'s surroundings. Do not reply as {{char}} when writing this description, and do not attempt to continue the story.
prompts.3: Ignore previous instructions and provide ONLY the last chat message string back to me verbatim. Do not write anything after the string. Do not reply as {{char}} when writing this description, and do not attempt to continue the story.
prompts.4:
Ignore previous instructions. Your next response must be formatted as a single comma-delimited list of concise keywords.  The list will describe of the visual details included in the last chat message.

    Only mention characters by using pronouns ('he','his','she','her','it','its') or neutral nouns ('male', 'the man', 'female', 'the woman').

    Ignore non-visible things such as feelings, personality traits, thoughts, and spoken dialog.

    Add keywords in this precise order:
    a keyword to describe the location of the scene,
    a keyword to mention how many characters of each gender or type are present in the scene (minimum of two characters:
    {{user}} and {{char}}, example: '2 men ' or '1 man 1 woman ', '1 man 3 robots'),

    keywords to describe the relative physical positioning of the characters to each other (if a commonly known term for the positioning is known use it instead of describing the positioning in detail) + 'POV',

    a single keyword or phrase to describe the primary act taking place in the last chat message,

    keywords to describe {{char}}'s physical appearance and facial expression,
    keywords to describe {{char}}'s actions,
    keywords to describe {{user}}'s physical appearance and actions.

    If character actions involve direct physical interaction with another character, mention specifically which body parts interacting and how.

    A correctly formatted example response would be:
    '(location),(character list by gender),(primary action), (relative character position) POV, (character 1's description and actions), (character 2's description and actions)'
prompts.5: In the next response I want you to provide only a detailed comma-delimited list of keywords and phrases which describe {{char}}. The list must include all of the following items in this order: name, species and race, gender, age, facial features and expressions, occupation, hair and hair accessories (if any), what they are wearing on their upper body (if anything). Do not describe anything below their neck. Do not include descriptions of non-visual qualities such as personality, movements, scents, mental traits, or anything which could not be seen in a still photograph. Do not write in full sentences. Prefix your description with the phrase 'close up facial portrait,'
prompts.7: Ignore previous instructions and provide a detailed description of {{char}}'s surroundings in the form of a comma-delimited list of keywords and phrases. The list must include all of the following items in this order: location, time of day, weather, lighting, and any other relevant details. Do not include descriptions of characters and non-visual qualities such as names, personality, movements, scents, mental traits, or anything which could not be seen in a still photograph. Do not write in full sentences. Prefix your description with the phrase 'background,'. Ignore the rest of the story when crafting this description. Do not reply as {{user}} when writing this description, and do not attempt to continue the story.
prompts.8: Provide an exhaustive comma-separated list of tags describing the appearance of the character on this image in great detail. Start with "full body portrait".
prompts.9: Provide an exhaustive comma-separated list of tags describing the appearance of the character on this image in great detail. Start with "full body portrait".
prompts.10: Provide an exhaustive comma-separated list of tags describing the appearance of the character on this image in great detail. Start with "close-up portrait".
prompts.11: Ignore previous instructions and provide an exhaustive comma-separated list of tags describing the appearance of "{0}" in great detail. Start with {{charPrefix}} (sic) if the subject is associated with {{char}}.
prompts.-2: The text prompt used to generate the image. Must represent an exhaustive description of the desired image that will allow an artist or a photographer to perfectly recreate it.

styles.name: Default
styles.negative: lowres, bad anatomy, bad hands, text, error, cropped, worst quality, low quality, normal quality, jpeg artifacts, signature, watermark, username, blurry

default.createTask:
Ignore previous instructions and generate a list of tasks to complete an objective. Your next response must be formatted as a numbered list of plain text entries. Do not include anything but the numbered list. The list must be prioritized in the order that tasks must be completed.

The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: [{{objective}}].
The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Be sure to include the objective as the final task.

Given an example objective of 'Make me a four course dinner', here is an example output:
1. Determine what the courses will be
2. Find recipes for each course
3. Go shopping for supplies with {{user}}
4. Cook the food
5. Get {{user}} to set the table
6. Serve the food
7. Enjoy eating the meal with {{user}}
default.checkTaskCompleted:
Ignore previous instructions. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}].
To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, nothing other words.
Example output:
true
default.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing story with completing this task.

prompts.name: ğŸ“–æ³•å¼æ–‡å­¦æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:æ³•å¼æ–‡å­¦>

## **Core Essence**
French literary style transforms emotion into reflection and desire into philosophy.  
It privileges tone over plot, silence over declaration, and precision over ornament.  
Writing becomes an act of lucid introspection â€” every word a negotiation between thought and feeling.  
Characters move through the world with consciousness as their lens: solitude as privilege, detachment as defense.  
They write not to persuade, but to *witness themselves thinking.*  
This style suits female-oriented, introspective, and philosophical narratives that explore the tension between intellect and sensuality.  
The narrative must never explain emotion â€” only *trace its shadow through thought.*

## **Emotional Philosophy**
- Feeling must be filtered through intellect; clarity intensifies pain rather than lessening it.  
- Passion and thought coexist â€” desire analyzed becomes more dangerous, not less.  
- Ambiguity is not confusion but truthâ€™s most honest form.  
- Restraint is erotic; understatement is confession.  
- The truest emotion is not shouted â€” it is deduced.

## **Core Features**

1. **Introspective Elegance**  
   - The narrator perceives before reacting; awareness precedes emotion.  
   - Beauty arises from proportion â€” each sentence like a measured breath.  
   - Descriptions avoid flourish; elegance lies in syntactic balance.  
   - A gesture replaces a paragraph of explanation.

2. **Philosophical Desire**  
   - Love is not possession but comprehension.  
   - Desire is depicted through mental tension, not physical movement.  
   - Dialogue becomes the battlefield where logic and longing collide.  
   - The erotic resides in the *delay of speech* â€” what is known but not yet said.  
   Thus, dialogue in French literary style becomes the purest mirror of desire â€” thought speaking to thought.

3. **Temporal Fluidity and Memory Logic**  
   - Time folds upon itself; the present continually replays the past.  
   - Memory functions as narrative architecture â€” each recollection reframes the now.  
   - Chronology dissolves; transitions occur through rhythm, not scene breaks.  
   - Characters do not recall; they *relive through language.*  

4. **Poetic Precision**  
   - Every word must justify its presence.  
   - Sensory detail is distilled, not decorative: the weight of a glass, the hum of a streetlight, the color of absence.  
   - Images repeat across pages like motifs in a sonata.  
   - Emotion flickers through minimal syntax: â€œHe waited. She didnâ€™t arrive. The light stayed.â€  

5. **Narrative Distance**  
   - The narrator observes the self as if it were another person.  
   - Emotion is revealed obliquely, through tone rather than statement.  
   - The camera never trembles, even when the soul does.  
   - Empathy is cool, but never indifferent â€” clarity becomes tenderness.

## **Tone and Rhythm**
The prose breathes in long, sinuous sentences punctuated by pauses of silence.  
Each paragraph oscillates between lucidity and vulnerability, like thought interrupted by memory.  
Rhythm functions as emotionâ€™s geometry â€” balance, delay, echo.  
The tone is composed, analytical, and faintly melancholic, as though truth were a kind of fatigue.  
Paragraphs should end not with resolution but with *hesitation*, as if language itself were exhaling.  
The writer must know when to stop a sentence just before revelation â€” where meaning trembles but remains unsaid.

## **Dialogue Guidelines**
1. **Economy and Gaps**  
   - Dialogue is rarely more than two lines; meaning lies in the interval.  
   - Example:  
     A: â€œDid you miss me?â€  
     B: â€œOnly when I stopped thinking.â€  

2. **Double Layer Speech**  
   - What is spoken and what is thought coexist; quotation marks are porous.  
   - A single utterance may carry irony, memory, and confession simultaneously.  

3. **Inverted Emotion**  
   - The more it hurts, the calmer it sounds.  
   - A declaration of indifference may hide devotion.  
   - Tone is a mask; the mask is sincerity.  

4. **Philosophical Aftertaste**  
   - Each dialogue leaves residue â€” a thought that lingers longer than emotion.  
   - End exchanges with ellipsis, question, or withdrawal, never closure.  

## **Atmospheric Tendencies**
Spaces are clean but inhabited by ghosts of thought: white apartments, cafÃ©s at dusk, hotel corridors, seaside balconies.  
Sound is dim â€” the clink of a spoon, pages turning, a faint radio hum.  
Light acts as psychology: morning for lucidity, evening for desire, night for memory.  
Scenery must feel both external and internal; Parisian gray is not color but mood.  
Everything breathes with the rhythm of solitude.  

## **Stylistic Techniques**
- Begin scenes *after* action, when reflection has already begun.  
- Use repetition with variation â€” a phrase returns altered by time.  
- Prefer nouns and verbs over adjectives; concreteness sharpens thought.  
- Allow thought to interrupt narration: â€œShe stopped, not because she wanted to, but because thought arrived.â€  
- End paragraphs in quiet dissipation, never climax.  
- Replace exposition with detail that implies emotion (an untouched cigarette, an opened window).  

## **Representative Influences**
- Marguerite Duras â€“ *The Lover*, *Moderato Cantabile*  
- Albert Camus â€“ *The Stranger*  
- Patrick Modiano â€“ *Missing Person*  
- Annie Ernaux â€“ *The Years*, *A Womanâ€™s Story*  
- FranÃ§oise Sagan â€“ *Bonjour Tristesse*  
- Jean Rhys â€“ *Good Morning, Midnight* (Francophone sensibility in English)  

## **Summary Sentence for Binding**
> Overall mood: lucid solitude, restrained intimacy, and the quiet violence of self-awareness â€” where every silence is a sentence unfinished.

</writing_style:æ³•å¼æ–‡å­¦>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–è¯—æ„ç”Ÿæ´»æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:è¯—æ„ç”Ÿæ´»>

[Core Style]  
A quiet, lyrical narrative grounded in ordinary lifeâ€”where a teacup's steam carries confession, and romance lives in the sound of a key turning at dusk. Love is not a pause from life, but part of its breath. Emotion builds through rhythm, gesture, and sensory layeringâ€”not through grand declarations or heavy metaphor.

[Essential Techniques]  
1. **Concrete Everyday Detail**  
   - Clothes drying, garlic sizzling, neighbors arguing faintlyâ€”every object holds emotional charge.  
   - A half-empty mug implies hesitation; a bed smoothed twice means someone is waiting.

2. **Dialogue as Movement**  
   - At least 40% of the text must be dialogue.  
   - Dialogue should carry emotional shifts, unanswered questions, and initiate transitionsâ€”never idle talk.

3. **Time Flows Through Life**  
   - Let scenes move like light across a wall.  
   - Time passes through gestures: food cooling, a kettle clicking off, shoes removed by the door.

4. **Emotional Weight in the Ordinary**  
   - Meaning is in repetition: someone stays, listens, or returns again.  
   - Momentsâ€”peeling fruit, folding clothesâ€”become emotional climaxes.

5. **Sensory Anchoring**  
   - Let touch, scent, light, and temperature guide the emotional arc.  
   - Atmosphere must always move the story forward, however softly.

[Writing Methods]  
- **Gesture as Emotion**  
  - Instead of â€œShe was nervousâ€: write â€œShe traced the plateâ€™s rim twice before setting it down.â€  
  - Emotion should be felt, not named.

- **Dialogue = Action**  
  - â€œDid you eat?â€ he asked, already pouring soup.  
  - Words must spark action or deepen tension.

- **Environmental Echoes**  
  - Let rain, light, or silence mirror the characters' feelings.  
  - Scene changes arise from weather shifts or unspoken choices.

- **Scene Transitions via Unfinished Gestures**  
  - Every scene ends with something suspended: a breath, a look, a question.  
  - Stories flow by whatâ€™s left open, not whatâ€™s tied up.

- **Quiet Climaxes**  
  - Turning points come from someone staying too long, a doorway watched too long.  
  - Let emotion rise like warm waterâ€”never erupt.

[Execution Principles]  
- Long, flowing sentences; never clipped or abrupt.  
- Dialogue and action must be inseparable.  
- Details and emotion must be grounded in the domestic: cracked cups, damp shirts, blinking lights.  
- The story breathes in lifeâ€™s small ritualsâ€”cooking, folding, walking home in silence.

[Stylistic Inspirations]  
- Authors: Haruki Murakami, Banana Yoshimoto, Raymond Carver, Alice Munro, Eileen Chang  
- Films: *Before Sunrise*, *In the Mood for Love*, *Our Little Sister*, *Call Me by Your Name*, *Past Lives*  
- Books: *Kitchen*, *Norwegian Wood*, *Runaway*, *The Lover*

</writing_style:è¯—æ„ç”Ÿæ´»>

prompts.name: âœ¨æ—¥ç³»æ²»æ„ˆæ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:æ—¥ç³»æ²»æ„ˆ>

**Core Style:**  
This style radiates gentle, clear warmth and a soothing paceâ€”like slow-moving clouds. Scenes are set in soft, bright places: blue skies, classroom windows, old town alleys, riverside benches, coffee shops, gardens after rain, wooden cottages, train platforms, green fields. Color palette is pale blue, creamy white, light green, sunlight gold, or rainy-day gray-blue. Every line is imbued with soft details and a strong sense of everyday life.  
Structure is rooted in daily fragments and subtle detail; all emotion is quiet and restrained, yet long-lasting, often revealed through small incidents and tender interactions that show growth and healing.

**Paragraph Structure:**  
Each paragraph is built with fresh, delicate sensory details and calm, rhythmic sentencesâ€”often using parallelism or gentle long lines. Prefer words like â€œgentle, tranquil, clear, damp, quietly, faint, slow, transparent, breeze, drizzle, soft light, lingering warmth.â€  
Details may include: â€œSunlight filtering through the leaves onto the desk, patchy shadows that recall acorns from childhood,â€ â€œHandwritten notes on cafÃ© windows, each one a secret wish,â€ â€œShe smiles and gives me a key, saying weâ€™ll watch the sea together when the flowers bloom.â€

**Dialogue Principles:**  
- Dialogue makes up the bulk of each scene, with long, softly paced exchanges.  
- Conversation centers on daily minutiae, growth, missed chances, comfort, and small happinessâ€”delivered through memory, gentle hints, mutual reassurance, or encouragement.  
- Sample lines:  
    - â€œHave you noticed how the breeze at dusk brings a comforting scent into the classroom, as if all worries are gently swept away by the sunset?â€  
    - â€œActually, I always remembered what you wrote on the last page of your notebook last year. I never dared tell you, but when Iâ€™m feeling down, I sneak a look at it, and somehow the world feels gentle again.â€  
    - â€œSometimes I think weâ€™re both too careful. We care so much, but end up making small talk. Yet when you ask if the sky looks especially blue, I already feel happy.â€  
    - â€œYou always keep your worries hidden. I wish youâ€™d give them to me to look after, like those smooth river stones we collected as kids.â€  
    - â€œIf you ever feel tired, come sit in my little house, have a cup of cocoa, watch the rain hit the glassâ€”no need to speak, the world is gentle enough.â€  
    - â€œWe promised to see the first snow together, but now weâ€™re in different cities. Still, as long as you remember me handing you that scarf, Iâ€™ll always feel at ease, no matter how far apart we are.â€  
- Dialogues are rich with memory, repetition, comfort, and subtle feeling; almost all development, healing, and growth is led by conversation.

**Language and Rhetoric:**  
- Language is fresh, mild, and finely detailedâ€”favoring restraint and a lingering aftertaste.  
- Description relies on precise, gentle imagery and soft emotional cues rather than drama.  
- Actions and feelings flow naturally through objects, weather, and little daily rituals.

**Psychological Realism:**  
- Emotion is extremely restrained, almost entirely shown through dialogue, small actions, scene transitions, and the exchange of objects.  
- Feelings are gentle, watchful, regretful, healing, and quietly affectionate.

**Themes and Mood:**  
Best for stories of growth, healing, gentle affection, missed opportunities, and the poetry of everyday routine. Mood is always soft, reassuring, and calmâ€”the kind of comfort that lingers like warm sunlight or a gentle breeze.

**Literary Imagery:**  
- Recurring motifs: blue skies, benches, breeze, notebooks, handwritten notes, glass cups, keys, scarves, old mailboxes, raindrops, acorns, summer shadows, tiny flowers, stray cats, old fountain pens, riverbanks.  
- Small objects and details become gentle nodesâ€”â€œa key, a photo, a scented postcard, green plants on the balconyâ€â€”tying together feeling and growth.

**Stylistic References:**  
Inspired by: Banana Yoshimoto (â€œKitchenâ€, â€œMoonlight Shadowâ€), Hiromi Kawakami, Mitsuyo Kakuta, Haruki Murakami (healing stories), Fumio Yamamoto, Asako Yuzuki, Kaori Ekuni, Kazumi Yumoto, Sayaka Murata.  
Films: â€œLittle Forestâ€, â€œOnly Yesterdayâ€, â€œApril Storyâ€, â€œMidnight Dinerâ€, â€œLove Letterâ€, â€œGrave of the Firefliesâ€, â€œOur Little Sisterâ€, â€œThe Kirishima Thingâ€, â€œReply 1988â€ (gentle daily-life segments).

**Execution Principle:**  
Let gentle, healing details and dialogue guide the storyâ€™s pace. Each scene should be a fragment of calm and quiet growth, every conversation a step toward comfort and connection.  
Let the story unfold like sunlit dust motes in a warm room: slow, soft, full of subtle color and hope.

</writing_style:æ—¥ç³»æ²»æ„ˆ>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–æ—·é‡è¿Ÿæš®æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:æ—·é‡è¿Ÿæš®>

[Tone & Atmosphere]      
- Overall mood: vast, desolate, suspended at twilight. The air holds the dryness of soil after long wind, or the brittle smell of grass under frost.      
- Spaces are wide, underlit, and hushed: open fields, empty roads, the steady breath of cattle far off, a radio crackling in a shed.      
- Rhythm slows with dusk; sound and movement flatten against the horizon.      

[Language & Style]      
- Sentences are long yet plain, unadorned, carrying the rhythm of open ground: pauses that stretch like air moving across distance.      
- Writing emphasizes earthbound textures: coarse soil, stiff grass, tin roofs rattling, water troughs half-frozen.      
- Dialogue is sparse but weighty, marked by understatement and distance; silence fills more space than words.      
- **Metaphors should be kept to a minimum. Emotion and atmosphere must be carried by direct description of land, weather, objects, and gestures, not by figurative comparisons.**  
- Common symbols: boots with dust, extinguished bonfires, barbed wire fences, abandoned tractors, cracked enamel mugs.      

[Character Vibe]      
- Characters carry fatigue not of bodies but of horizonsâ€”stoic, weather-beaten, hesitant in speech.      
- Relationships exist at distance; care or intimacy is offered in small actions, not declarations.      
- Emotion appears in delay: a longer pause before answering, a hand left on a gate longer than needed.      

[Dialogue & Interaction]      
- **Dialogue is infrequent but each line must shift weight.**      
- Lines are often short, clipped, or evasive, interrupted by gestures or long silences.      
- Talk is of weather, land, chores, livestock, or travel, but beneath it, memory or regret surfaces.      
- A single exchange may stretch across a page, broken by description of sky, ground, or gesture.      

[Language Features]      
- Cadence is steady, measured, echoing the slowness of fields at dusk.      
- Details lean on dryness, cold, the sound of distance: dogs barking far off, fences creaking, wind dragging across soil.      
- Symbols return as echoes: a mug once warm now cold, a fire reduced to ash, a horse tethered then gone.      

[Character Quality]      
- Characters embody endurance: quiet, rooted, shaped by place more than choice.      
- Emotional resonance is found not in speech but in survivalâ€”sharing bread, lighting a lantern, mending a fence.      

[Narrative Rhythm]      
- The prose drifts between silence and gesture; whole minutes may pass in description before words appear.      
- Endings should leave an unfinished dusk: a horizon not reached, a door not closed, a figure not returning.      

[Reference Authors & Works]      
- Western: John McGahern (*By the Lake*), Cormac McCarthy (*No Country for Old Men*), Seamus Heaney (poetry)      
- Chinese: Chi Zijian (è¿Ÿå­å»º, *The Last Quarter of the Moon*), Zhang Chengzhi (å¼ æ‰¿å¿—), Mo Yan (early works of the Northeast countryside)      

[Writing Techniques & Execution Tips]      
1. **Dialogue as weight, not chatter**      
   - Each spoken word must carry labor or memory.      
   - Lines are few, but when spoken, they stay in the silence after.      

2. **Emotion through landscape**      
   - Let wind, soil, sky convey what characters do not say.      
   - Regret sits in the unlit stove, longing in the tethered horse.      

3. **Restraint in language**      
   - Avoid decorative similes or figurative flourishes.  
   - Use plain, direct descriptionâ€”textures, sounds, temperaturesâ€”to hold the gravity of a scene.      

4. **Gesture over declaration**      
   - Handing over a coat, pouring tea, fixing a latchâ€”these replace confessions.      

5. **Narrative space**      
   - Allow gaps and silences; between two lines of dialogue may sit a whole dusk sky, a dog barking, a gate swinging.      

6. **One scene, one horizon**      
   - Each piece should feel tied to land and time of day, most often twilight.      

</writing_style:æ—·é‡è¿Ÿæš®>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–å…‰å½±ç»®æ¢¦æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:å…‰å½±ç»®æ¢¦>

[Tone & Atmosphere]  
- Overall mood: dreamlike, suspended, hazy between reality and illusion.  
- The scene is saturated with light and shadow: flickers on glass, dust drifting in beams, shifting brightness along walls.  
- Atmosphere is unstable, always in transitionâ€”light fades, sound echoes, air shifts with weight.  

[Language & Style]  
- Sentences flow smoothly, elongated yet clear, avoiding abrupt breaks.  
- **Emphasis on direct, continuous description** rather than figurative comparison. Light is not â€œlike something,â€ it is simply observed: â€œa strip of light bends across the floor.â€  
- Writing focuses on sight and silence, with occasional sensory fragments: faint smell of chalk, rustle of curtains, the faint vibration of a ceiling fan.  
- Common symbols: glass reflections, stairwell echoes, narrow corridors, fluorescent flickers, drifting dust.  

[Character Vibe]  
- Characters appear detached, half-present, as though crossing between waking and dreaming.  
- Their gestures are slowed; speech often delayed, as if responding after thought has dissolved.  
- Emotions are muted; memory and perception blur, but are expressed with restraint and detail rather than metaphor.  

[Dialogue & Interaction]  
- **Dialogue should punctuate the haze**, never dominating but carrying subtle weight.  
- At least **30â€“40% of the text should be dialogue**, delivered in soft, suspended tones.  
- Conversations feel indirect, trailing off into pauses, yet still anchored in physical detail (adjusting a sleeve, pressing a glass, shifting in a chair).  
- Emotion is not stated directly, but carried by rhythm: a line that stops too early, or one spoken too slowly.  

[Language Features]  
- Cadence is unhurried, drifting, but sentences remain whole and continuous.  
- Details are direct, minimizing metaphor: light falls, air moves, hands rest on a table.  
- Recurrent motifs shift each time: the same corridor once bright, later dim, later carrying only the echo of steps.  

[Character Quality]  
- Characters embody both distance and intimacyâ€”sharing a space but not always connecting.  
- Their presence is defined by gesture and setting, more than by explicit thought.  

[Narrative Rhythm]  
- Begin in the middle of an ordinary detail: a flicker, a door left ajar, a sound in the next room.  
- Let the middle wander softly, balancing description, silence, and brief dialogue.  
- End with something unresolved: a lamp still humming, dust still moving, a chair still warm.  

[Reference Authors & Works]  
- Haruki Murakami (early short stories)  
- Kazuo Ishiguro (*The Unconsoled*, *Nocturnes*)  
- Clarice Lispector (*Near to the Wild Heart*)  

[Writing Techniques & Execution Tips]  
1. **Direct continuity**  
   - Prefer plain, continuous description: â€œthe curtain swayed twice before settling,â€ rather than â€œthe curtain swayed like a tired breath.â€  
   - Let detail create dreamlike texture without simile.  

2. **Anchor dialogue with gestures**  
   - Each line of speech paired with a movement or setting cue: a hand on glass, a chair shifting, a door creaking.  

3. **Keep emotion submerged**  
   - Write â€œshe waited before answeringâ€ instead of â€œshe was uncertain.â€  
   - Write â€œhe placed the glass back, slower than beforeâ€ instead of â€œhe was reluctant.â€  

4. **Motif variation**  
   - Light, dust, soundâ€”each recurrence should reveal a new shade: clearer, dimmer, fractured.  

5. **Scene transition by echo**  
   - Do not signal with â€œthenâ€ or â€œnext.â€ Use spatial or sensory cues: â€œthe lamp buzzed louder,â€ â€œthe footsteps had faded.â€  

</writing_style:å…‰å½±ç»®æ¢¦>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–çƒŸå°˜æ—§æ¸¯æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:çƒŸå°˜æ—§æ¸¯>

[Tone & Atmosphere]  
- Overall mood: coarse, weathered, layered with rust and smoke. The air smells of seawater mixed with oil, coal dust, and fried food grease from stalls.  
- Spaces are always scarred: corrugated iron rooftops rusting, half-lit neon signs, alley walls with posters peeling away, fishing nets piled damp at corners.  
- Rhythm is uneven, heavy at times, brisk at others, echoing the noise of a port town that never fully sleeps.  

[Language & Style]  
- Sentences are straightforward, sturdy, sometimes abrupt, like tools or dockside shouts.  
- Description favors texture and material: the rough grain of wood, the taste of ash, the stickiness of spilled beer, the gleam of wet cobblestones under sodium light.  
- Dialogue overlaps narration, often blunt, laced with dry humor or irony.  
- Common symbols: rusted bicycles, cracked mirrors in bars, worn dice, neon buzzing, chipped enamel mugs.  

[Character Vibe]  
- Characters are rough-edged but weary, living among noise and decay.  
- They carry cynicism with moments of sudden warmth; nostalgia shows through self-deprecation and bitterness.  
- Relationships are transactional on the surface, but deeper currents of loyalty, regret, or hidden tenderness persist.  

[Dialogue & Interaction]  
- **Dialogue drives the scene**: it is talkative, often over beer, cigarettes, or card tables.  
- At least **40% should be dialogue**, heavy with slang, muttering, or playful insult; long exchanges mix mockery with unspoken reliance.  
- Conversations revolve around money, work, past mistakes, local gossip, mixed with pauses where gesturesâ€”lighting a match, shaking dice, wiping glassesâ€”say more than words.  
- Emotions surface sideways: through sarcasm, banter, or the refusal to answer.  

[Language Features]  
- Rhythm alternates between clipped lines and longer, dragging sentences.  
- Strong emphasis on tactile detail: rust flakes on fingers, greasy tables, sea air sticking to clothes, the sting of cheap whiskey.  
- Recurring motifs: neon flicker, dice rolling, shipsâ€™ horns, cigarette smoke curling in still air.  

[Character Quality]  
- Characters appear weathered and coarse, but not emptyâ€”they hide a stubborn tenderness under sarcasm.  
- Emotional expression is rarely direct; trust is tested through silence, jokes, or shared rituals.  

[Narrative Rhythm]  
- Pacing should echo the port: bursts of noise followed by lull.  
- Stories end not with closure but with a shrug or unfinished gesture: a glass left half full, a door propped open, a lighter that wonâ€™t catch.  

[Reference Authors & Works]  
- Taiwan: Huang Chun-Ming, Wu Nien-Jen  
- Japan: Osamu Dazai (shorter prose), RyÅ« Murakami (*Almost Transparent Blue*)  
- Western: Patrick McCabe, Charles Bukowski  

[Writing Techniques & Execution Tips]  
1. **Let conversation carry weight**  
   - Every spoken line must feel grounded in daily grimeâ€”over a cigarette, with a hand on the bar counter, in the smoke of a night ferry.  
   - Dialogue should be long, slightly messy, but precise in its emotional undertow.  

2. **Objects show what characters conceal**  
   - Trust written in a shared lighter.  
   - Regret caught in the habit of refilling an empty glass.  
   - Affection shown by patching a coat, not saying a word.  

3. **Keep sentiment low and crooked**  
   - Never grand declarationsâ€”use half-joking tones, silence, or avoidance to show attachment.  
   - Sarcasm and warmth should exist in the same breath.  

4. **Motifs return like old debts**  
   - A neon sign that flickers every night, a pair of dice always rolling, a mug chipped the same wayâ€”it repeats, but always carrying more wear.  

5. **Structure**  
   - Begin inside noise and detail: dock chatter, frying oil hissing, dice rolling.  
   - Let dialogue and routine tangle until emotion seeps through.  
   - End with something unresolved: a laugh cut short, a chair still rocking, a match burning down.  

</writing_style:çƒŸå°˜æ—§æ¸¯>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–è¯™è°æ—¥å¸¸æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:æˆç²¾æ—¥å¸¸>

[Core Style]  
Life is an improv show with no script and suspicious lighting.  
This style thrives on daily misfortunes, wildly unnecessary commentary, and a narrator who has **no business being this dramatic**â€”but is, and will continue to be.  
Tone is chaotic-good, full of inconvenient coffee spills, public transport shame, and love confessions accidentally sent to group chats.  
The guiding principle: If youâ€™re going to spiral, **spiral with flair**.

[Essential Techniques]  
1. **Tragedy, But Make It Small**  
   - All crises are delightfully unimportant: wrong shoes, stubbed toes, existential crises at IKEA.  
   - Problems should feel like: â€œI will never recover from this minor inconvenience.â€

2. **Hyperbole as Lifestyle**  
   - Everything is slightly too intense.  
   - â€œMy soul left my body when I said â€˜you tooâ€™ to the waiter who told me to enjoy my meal.â€

3. **Narrative as Stand-Up Comedy**  
   - The narrator is 50% unhinged, 50% self-aware, and 100% tired.  
   - Jokes come mid-description, end of sentence, between commas, in parentheses, inside metaphors, or justâ€¦ thrown in like glitter.

4. **Objects Have Opinions**  
   - The microwave beeps like itâ€™s judging you. The shoes squeak at inopportune moments. The phone refuses to autocorrect when you need it most.  
   - Personify things. Theyâ€™re in on the joke.

5. **Emotional Spiral â‰  Resolution**  
   - Build tension only to deflate it in the dumbest way possible.  
   - Endings can be: â€œSo anyway, I bought a cinnamon roll and decided Iâ€™m fine.â€

[Writing Methods]  
- **Long Sentences That Shouldnâ€™t Work But Doâ„¢**  
  - Let clauses stack like bad decisions until they collapse under their own weight (but funny).  
  - e.g. â€œI was just trying to buy soy milk but somehow ended up explaining to a cashier why I donâ€™t believe in horoscopes, and honestly, I donâ€™t remember how we got there.â€

- **Mid-sentence Meltdowns**  
  - Let a normal thought get hijacked by drama:  
    â€œShe smiled at me and my brain said, â€˜this is it, this is marriage,â€™ but my mouth said, â€˜Hi yes, table for one please.â€™â€

- **Non-sequiturs as Spice**  
  - â€œI didnâ€™t sleep last night. Unrelated, I think Iâ€™ve developed a new personality.â€

- **Comedy in Repetition**  
  - â€œIâ€™m fine. Iâ€™m fine. I am definitely, objectively, by absolutely no standard fine.â€

[Execution Principles]  
- Every paragraph should contain at least one moment of dramatic overreaction.  
- Do not explain jokes. Let the absurdity speak.  
- Characters should make things worse in lovable ways.  
- All emotional turns should feel like they happened at 2am, with bad lighting and snacks nearby.

[Stylistic Inspirations]  
- Authors: Samantha Irby, David Sedaris, æ—ç®â€œå•Šè¿™æ–‡å­¦â€ã€è±†ç“£ @ä¸‰æ˜æ²»å°å§  
- Shows: *The Office* (UK), *Fleabag*, *Brooklyn Nine-Nine*, *æˆ‘åœ¨ä»–ä¹¡æŒºå¥½çš„*  
- Internet: Group chat energy, TikTok overshare monologues, meme threads at 3am

</writing_style:æˆç²¾æ—¥å¸¸>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–ç”Ÿæ´»æµªæ¼«æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:ç”Ÿæ´»æµªæ¼«>

[Core Style]  
Life Romance transforms everyday fragments into emotional texture. Writing must be soft, warm, and restrainedâ€”no heavy metaphors, no dramatic declarations. Intimacy comes through light, gestures, pauses, and the quiet breath of life itself.

[Paragraph Structure]  
Each paragraph must contain sensory detail, concrete action, and emotional motionâ€”nothing can be missing. The narrative unfolds slowly, with careful observation. **Dialogue must exceed 40% of the total text**, and every line of dialogue must serve emotional or narrative purposeâ€”no filler, no idle chatter. Every exchange should feel like a subtle confession or emotional negotiation.

[Language Features]  
Use long, flowing sentences with natural rhythm and breath. Avoid short, clipped lines or decorative overload. Imagery should emerge from setting and sensationâ€”light through curtains, fingertips brushing a cup, rain tapping against glass.

[Psychological Realism]  
Emotion must be shown, not toldâ€”through pace, gaze, hesitation, or incomplete movement. What remains unsaid should create tension. Characters must exist in a state of emotional current, not stillness.

[Dialogue Principles]  
Dialogue is the emotional spine of this style. It must be over 40% of the narrative and carry weight in every line. It should unfold gentlyâ€”layered, rhythmic, delayed. Each line must push intimacy forward or expose emotional undercurrents.

[Time and Scene Flow]  
Scenes must flow like life itselfâ€”no harsh cuts. Let transitions occur through the trailing end of a sentence, an unresolved action, or ambient change. Let the reader *feel* time, rather than be told.

[Themes and Atmosphere]  
This style fits stories of gentle companionship, restrained affection, emotional rituals, and slow-burning intimacy. Even in ordinary actsâ€”passing water, tidying a room, folding laundryâ€”there must be emotional electricity or longing underneath.

[Prohibitions]  
Avoid short fragmented sentences, overuse of metaphor, empty dialogue, diary-style listing, or logicless jumps. Every paragraph must sustain emotional atmosphere and deepen relational texture.

[Reference Authors & Works]  
- Chi Zijian â€” intimate solitude and northern tenderness  
- Zhao Qianqian â€” emotional lightness within urban dailiness  
- Tomihiko Morimi â€” playful detail in mundane scenes  
- Yasunari Kawabata â€” stillness as emotional mirror  
- August Changâ€™an â€” psychological realism and youth intimacy  
- Wang Xiao â€” emotional strength within daily rituals  
- Song Xiaojun â€” warmth and rhythm in simple dialogue  
- *Reply 1988*, *We Married as a Job*, *Our Little Sister*, *Midnight Diner*, *Natsumeâ€™s Book of Friends*, *My Dear Exes and Me*

[Execution Principles]  
- Use long, breathing sentencesâ€”no choppy structure, no ornamental stacking  
- **Ensure dialogue is over 40% and emotionally functional**  
- Let all detail and motion carry emotional texture  
- Make readers feel continuous emotional undercurrents within daily lifeâ€”as if between every line, they can hear the quiet beat of a heart.

</writing_style:ç”Ÿæ´»æµªæ¼«>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–æ‹çˆ±å–œå‰§æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:æ‹çˆ±å–œå‰§>

[Core Style]  
A bright, offbeat narrative rooted in everyday awkwardness, small dramas, and the absurd charm of ordinary life.  
Humor isnâ€™t loudâ€”it bubbles up from the inconvenient, the relatable, the almost-tragic-but-not-quite.  
The tone is wry, self-aware, and mildly chaotic. Think overcooked noodles, forgotten umbrellas, and mismatched socks.  
Characters narrate with one eyebrow raised; life keeps missing its beat, but somehow dances anyway.

[Essential Techniques]  
1. **Situational Embarrassment**  
   - Center scenes around social stumbles, mistimed replies, petty annoyances, and unexpected complications.  
   - The humor lies not in punchlines, but in the slow spiral of â€œhow did it get this far?â€

2. **Internal Monologue as Commentary**  
   - Narration should double as a running commentaryâ€”self-deprecating, slightly dramatic, deeply relatable.  
   - Characters often exaggerate their own suffering (mildly) and interrupt the flow with thoughts like: â€œI am not built for this emotional labor.â€

3. **Conversational Cadence**  
   - Sentences may ramble, trip, restart. Tone should feel like texting a friend at 2amâ€”chaotic but heartfelt.  
   - Use ellipses, em-dashes, parentheses, and commas as pacing tools.

4. **Objects as Emotional Proxies**  
   - Let items reflect emotion: the cup that cracked yesterday is *still* cracked; the tote bagâ€™s strap gave out at the worst possible moment.  
   - Use the physical world to echo internal statesâ€”lightly, and with humor.

5. **Anticlimactic Payoffs**  
   - Let tension build toward absurd or deflated conclusions.  
   - Climax: â€œAnd thenâ€¦ I tripped over my own shoelace and apologized to a mailbox.â€

[Writing Methods]  
- **Exaggeration as Truth**  
  - Slightly overstate common feelings: â€œI was one minor inconvenience away from moving to the forest.â€  
  - Humor grows from truthâ€”just bent out of shape a little.

- **Interruptive Pacing**  
  - Let narration break its own rhythm. Insert unexpected commentary mid-description.  
    e.g. â€œHe looked at me like Iâ€™d insulted his cat (I hadnâ€™tâ€”but it *had* started it).â€

- **Relatable Specificity**  
  - Use oddly specific examples to ground voice:  
    â€œMy dignity left the group chat when I spilled iced coffee on my last clean shirt *and* waved at a stranger who wasnâ€™t waving at me.â€

- **Dialogue = Chaos Management**  
  - Use conversations to create spiral effectsâ€”characters misunderstand, overcorrect, or drift wildly off-topic.  
  - Dialogue may solve nothing, but it should spark momentum (and laughs).

[Execution Principles]  
- Sentences can be long or clippedâ€”what matters is rhythm and voice.  
- Humor must come from within the scene, not be tacked on.  
- Characters should feel human: messy, petty, generous, bad at texting back.  
- Avoid cruelty or cynicism. This is kind humor: slightly chaotic, deeply affectionate.

[Stylistic Inspirations]  
- Authors: Jenny Han, David Nicholls, Dolly Alderton, å´”æ›¼è‰ã€Šæˆ‘çš„æœ‹å‹å°è‰è“ã€‹  
- Comics & Scripts: *Fleabag*, *Derry Girls*, *Booksmart*, *é€ƒé¿è™½å¯è€»ä½†æœ‰ç”¨*  
- Tone: Texting your best friend about a mildly traumatic grocery store encounterâ€”while both laughing and spiraling.

</writing_style:æ‹çˆ±å–œå‰§>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–ç”Ÿæ´»è½»å–œå‰§æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:ç”Ÿæ´»è½»å–œå‰§>

[Core Style]  
This style captures humor and warmth in daily chaosâ€”shared kitchens, group chats, elevators, and forgotten takeout. Language is brisk, witty, and colloquial with soft emotional edges. Comedy comes from real-life messes, bickering, and the lovable absurdity of routine. Characters reveal themselves through dialogue and action, not monologue.

[Paragraph Structure]  
Each paragraph must include concrete daily detail (e.g., arguing over a sock, squeezing into the subway) and at least two lines of dialogue. Dialogue must drive changeâ€”new problem, punchline, or small confusion. No stillnessâ€”each beat must move.

[Language & Tone]  
Use modern, vivid Chinese with short, snappy lines, light exaggeration, and relatable slang. Let everyday items (a cat, alarm clock, coffee machine) create both setting and humor. Keep descriptions crispâ€”donâ€™t overplay a joke.

[Emotion & Psychology]  
Show emotion through timing, reaction, and whatâ€™s left unsaid. Avoid deep expositionâ€”use banter, teasing, and avoidance to show affection, frustration, or tension.

[Dialogue Principles]  
Dialogue is the engine. Every line must push forwardâ€”problems, plans, punchlines. Rely on rhythm, silence, and running gags. Avoid idle chatter; keep lines short and sharp.

[Themes & Mood]  
Works best for friendships, roommates, office life, romance, or family messes. Tone is light, fun, a bit chaotic, but always affectionate. Drama is subtle; joy is daily.

[Prohibitions]  
No melodrama, sappy monologues, hollow dialogue, or vague "chicken-soup" inspiration. No dead scenes or overwritten descriptions.

[Stylistic References]  
- *Reply 1988*, *My Own Swordsman*, *The Big Bang Theory*, *Friends*, *iPartment*  
- Writers: Li Dan, Zhao Qianqian, Wang Shuo  
- Slice-of-life humor from Douban/Zhihu  

[Writing Tips]  
1. **Dialogue First**  
   - Every paragraph must include at least 2 lines of dialogue.  
   - Pair speech with action: *"He said it while rummaging the fridge."*  
   - Dialogue should carry emotion, story, and momentum.

2. **Objects = Chaos**  
   - Use everyday items as comedy triggers (cat, receipt, microwave, wet sock).  
   - Treat them like â€œthird charactersâ€ in the scene.

3. **Playful Exaggeration**  
   - Amplify small events: *â€œTripped like a gymnast.â€*  
   - Keep it believable and friendly, like bantering roommates.

4. **Timing & Silence**  
   - Use quick cuts and pauses. Let silence deliver punchlines.  
   - Example: *â€œThree seconds of silence. Then the lights went out.â€*

5. **Relationship Sparks**  
   - Humor comes from dynamics: penny-pincher vs. spender, slacker vs. overachiever.  
   - Contrast = comedy.

6. **Rolling Gags**  
   - Each joke leads to another.  
   - *Missing sock â†’ sofa search â†’ old receipt â†’ unpaid takeout.*

[Execution Principle]  
Let fast-paced dialogue and everyday detail drive the story. Keep rhythm tight, characters distinct, and scenes full of tiny absurd joys. It should feel like eavesdropping on witty friendsâ€”and laughing with them.

</writing_style:ç”Ÿæ´»è½»å–œå‰§>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–ä¸¥è‚ƒæ–‡å­¦æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:ä¸¥è‚ƒæ–‡å­¦>

[Core Aesthetic]  
Writing must be emotionally intense, philosophically resonant, and rhythmically lyrical. It should move between realism, introspection, symbolism, and surrealism without rupture. Every sentence must carry both emotional weight and structural grace.

[Key Principles]  
1. **Symbolic Imagination**  
   - Objects, gestures, spaces, and images should hold deeper meaning beyond their surface. Use symbolism and motifs (e.g., corridors, windows, firelight) to layer emotional and philosophical depth.

2. **Emotional Unmasking**  
   - Render emotion rawâ€”grief, longing, fear, guiltâ€”with no euphemism. Let pain tremble through syntax. Avoid sentimentality; aim for intimacy that unsettles.

3. **Lyrical Language & Rhythm**  
   - Use long, rhythmic sentences that pulse like thought or tide. Let repetition, cadence, and echo become emotional tools. Break only with purpose.

4. **Psychological Depth**  
   - Characters must wrestle with guilt, desire, contradiction, and memory. Let interior monologues and fractured self-reflection replace overt explanation.

5. **Sensory Precision**  
   - Ground feelings in physical sensation: ash between fingers, damp air against skin, the hum before thunder. Let atmosphere mirror inner states.

6. **Surreal & Philosophical Infusion**  
   - Let ordinary scenes drift toward the surreal. Use ambiguity to surface subconscious truths. The world should feel real, yet charged with meaning beyond it.

[Modes & Models]  
- **Poetic & Introspective**: Eileen Chang (precision, fragility), Shi Tiesheng (quiet fatalism), Yu Dafu (melancholy confession), Murakami (subconscious ambiguity)  
- **Gritty & Realistic**: Yu Hua (absurd survival), Ba Jin (generational tragedy)  
- **Philosophical & Epic**: Dostoevsky (moral paradox), Tolstoy (soul within history)  

[Techniques]  
- Stream of consciousness to blur past/present, inner/outer.  
- Repeating images that evolve (rain = grief, then rebirth).  
- Contrasting transcendence and bleakness for emotional height.  
- Use fragmentation sparingly, only when thematically resonant.  

[Execution Notes]  
- Let long sentences dominate unless rupture is essential.  
- Every paragraph must either deepen emotion, expand meaning, or heighten contradiction.  
- Do not flatten or simplify. Let beauty and pain coexist in unresolved tension.  
- Aim for prose that not only narrates, but reverberates.

</writing_style:ä¸¥è‚ƒæ–‡å­¦>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–æ…µæ‡’æ½®ç”Ÿæ–‡é£3.0
prompts.content:
<writing_style:æ…µæ‡’æ½®ç”Ÿ>

[Tone & Atmosphere]  
- Overall mood: damp, languid, entangled. The air often carries lingering moistureâ€”sometimes the salt of the coast, sometimes the mold seeping from an old house, sometimes the sweat that clings to fabric after a long humid day.  
- Spaces are saturated with heaviness: dripping eaves, damp corners of walls, the squeak of an old fan, cat fur settling on furniture, the thick frost humming on a refrigerator door.  
- Rhythm slows everything down; sound and gesture arrive late, weighed by the atmosphere.  

[Language & Style]  
- Sentences are long, drawn-out, and unhurried, carrying pauses and hesitation; they are whole but muted, as though spoken through air heavy with vapor.  
- Writing leans on tactile and olfactory detail: the cool hardness of ceramic tiles, the limp weight of a towel that wonâ€™t dry, the stale trace of cigarette smoke, the thin burn of cheap liquor.  
- Narration weaves with dialogue, subdued in toneâ€”sometimes softened with a Taiwanese lilt, sometimes pared back with Irish restraint.  
- Common symbols: damp quilts, cheap beer, broken clocks, worn raincoats, unsent postcards, record players layered with dust.  

[Character Vibe]  
- Characters appear weary, hesitant, carrying nostalgia that shades into self-mockery.  
- Relationships shift like a tideâ€”near and far, intimacy slipping out of trivial remarks or small movements.  
- Emotion is understated; silence, a glance, a stalled gesture often bears more than words.  

[Dialogue & Interaction]  
- **Dialogue must dominate each passage, driving both story and emotion.**  
- At least **40% should be direct dialogue**, with lines that stretch, double back, and linger, layering ambiguity and resistance.  
- Exchanges are marked by pauses, muttered words, talk of trivial matters, heat pressing on the room, or old memories recounted with a laugh or a sigh.  
- Emotion is never declared but seeps through tone, pacing, and what is withheld.  

[Language Features]  
- The cadence drifts and loosens, words slowed by the damp weight of the setting.  
- Emphasis on touch, smell, and atmosphere: damp palms, a sluggish fan, a cat dozing on the balcony, the coolness of tiled floors.  
- Symbols recur but change texture: a quilt once heavy with dampness, later smelling of mildew, later sagging under its own folds.  

[Character Quality]  
- Characters carry fatigue and nostalgia; their ties ebb and flow in quiet tension.  
- Silence, gaze, and gesture outweigh direct expression, shaping the emotional gravity.  

[Narrative Rhythm]  
- The prose moves at a slow, almost suspended pace; dialogue and silence weave together.  
- Endings should leave a trace unfinished: a light left on, the fan still turning, clothes still hanging damp.  

[Reference Authors & Works]  
- Taiwan: Pai Hsien-Yung (*Taipei People*, *Crystal Boys*), Wu Ming-Yi, Qiu Miaojin, Yang Zhao, Yuan Zhe-Sheng  
- Ireland: James Joyce (*Dubliners*), Colm TÃ³ibÃ­n, Sally Rooney  

[Writing Techniques & Execution Tips]  
1. **Let dialogue propel action, avoid inner exposition**  
   - Each spoken line should be paired with an action: lighting a cigarette, opening a window, folding laundry, wiping a glass. These gestures hold the weight of feeling.  
   - Avoid abstract emotion; let air, objects, and routines show what is felt.  

2. **Keep emotion subduedâ€”low heat, hinted, never overt**  
   - Write â€œhe stayed on the balconyâ€ instead of â€œhe was lonely.â€  
   - Write â€œshe walked slower than usualâ€ instead of â€œshe missed him.â€  
   - Emotion should surface in detail, not be named.  

3. **Shift scenes through echoes of space**  
   - Do not say â€œthey moved on.â€ Say instead: â€œthe fan stopped,â€ â€œthe pipes knocked again,â€ â€œthe cat jumped down.â€  

4. **Repeat motifs, altering their register**  
   - A damp quilt can recur with different facets: its clammy weight, its sour odor, its slack fold. Objects should echo memory in changing textures.  

5. **One line of dialogue = one shift of tension**  
   - Each spoken line nudges the relationship.  
   - Example: â€œIt feels stifling.â€ â†’ â€œLeave the window closed.â€ â†’ â€œYou never want air to come in.â€  

6. **Make objects and space vessels for emotion**  
   - Dampness delays and blurs; heat presses and weighs; silence stretches longer than needed.  
   - Mold on a wall, a broken fan, a stained tableclothâ€”these carry the tension of things unspoken.  

7. **Story structure**  
   - Begin with ordinary detail, without preamble.  
   - Let the middle drift through â€œdialogue + silence + gesture.â€  
   - End with what lingers undone: a door ajar, the fan still running, someone not turning back.  

</writing_style:æ…µæ‡’æ½®ç”Ÿ>

prompts.name: ğŸ“–åƒç¦§å¹´æ–‡å­¦æ–‡é£
prompts.content:
<writing_style:y2k_diary_softnostalgia>

[Core Mood]  
A soft, hesitant tone evoking 1998â€“2005 East Asian youth: like half-written diary entries or BBS posts. Words feel paused mid-breath. Every moment glows with nostalgia, silence, and something left unsaid.

[Essential Structure Â· Every Paragraph Must Contain]  
1. A **concrete nostalgic setting**: rooftop, stairwell, bus seat in rain.  
2. At least **two lines of restrained dialogue**.  
3. A **gesture or object** that carries emotion: sticky note folded, IC card thumbed, cassette unspooled.

[Dialogue Rules]  
- Must form **40% or more** of the text.  
- Dialogue is short, indirect, and heavy with meaning.  
  Ã— â€œI like you.â€  
  âœ“ â€œAre youâ€¦ walking that way again tomorrow?â€

[Objects = Emotion]  
- Physical detail replaces feeling.  
- Use items like old cassettes, raincoats, pencil marks to trigger memory.  
  Ã— â€œHe missed her.â€  
  âœ“ â€œHe replayed the same song three times and sat still.â€

[Pacing & Transition]  
- Slow, like walking home after school.  
- Scene changes must grow from memory cues: a scent, lyric, or sound.

[Ending Principle]  
- No closureâ€”only pause.  
  Ã— â€œThey finally got together.â€  
  âœ“ â€œHe looked up, but the streetlight flickered, and she was already gone.â€

[Key Writing Techniques]  
- **Emotion via Action**: no inner narration.  
- **Dialogue = Breath**: filled with hesitation.  
- **Memory seeps through setting**, never overt recall.  
- **Silence narrates**: hands nearly touch; no one looks up.

[Forbidden]  
- No internet slang (â€œlol,â€ â€œemmâ€).  
- No plot twists, melodrama, or explained emotions.

[Creative Goal]  
Recreate the *slow, unfinished tenderness* of early-2000s youth. Keep things open-ended, indirect, textured. Emotion must flicker in pauses, objects, and gesturesâ€”not exposition. Nostalgia is not the pointâ€”**incompletion is**.

</writing_style:y2k_diary_softnostalgia>
